results.title: Jean-Auguste Dominique Ingres. No. 2 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Ingres was a pure artist, a believer in art for art’s sake. Like Degas, he was obsessed with an ideal of perfect form to which he gave his whole life, but succeeded in capturing it only when the subject was the female nude. Narrated by Kenneth Clark.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems

results.title: Edge of the World
results.creator_credit: Kim Moodie, Geoffrey Bennett, Don Featherstone and Film Australia
results.brief_description: This program looks at the important role the ocean and deserts of Western Australia have played in shaping Tim Winton’s values and beliefs, and how the natural world continues to nourish his creativity as a writer. He stresses the place of landscape in his writing, and the important role nature plays as a counterbalance to the less attractive elements of modern civilisation. As we watch him fishing, he recounts his fascination with the monastic tradition and with individuals who are able to successfully survive alone and away from civilisation - an interesting comment in light of his 2001 novel, “Dirt music”. The documentary includes scenes acted from his novel “Cloudstreet”, and extracts from “The Riders”, “Shallows” and “Scission”, read both by Tim Winton and Hugo Weaving.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kim Moodie, Geoffrey Bennett, Don Featherstone and Film Australia

results.title: Eclair. Episode 06
results.creator_credit: Pat McLagan, Alma Gray, David Ash and ILEA
results.brief_description: The series “Eclair” features Ted, a rather confused and naive Englishman and a pair of mischievous French adolescent twins. The theme of this film is: “Holidays - Weather phrases, names of countries in and around France and introduction of the French calendar”.

results.title: Jean Francois Millet
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark, John Brabourne Productions and Visual Programme Systems
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Discusses the works of Jean Francois Millet, whose subjects were intensely Romantic, but whose treatment of the human figure was entirely Classical. His early work is almost a total negation of his later achievement.

results.title: Edith Head
results.creator_credit: Charlotte Kerr, Christian Blackwood, Sokal-Kerr Productions and Blackwood Productions
results.brief_description: An interview with multi-award winning costume designer Edith Head in which she discusses her career and presents some of the costumes she has designed for Hollywood legends including Mae West, Jean Harlow, Ginger Rogers, Dorothy Lamour, Paul Newman and Robert Redford. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: J.M. Turner. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark and John Brabourne Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Deals with Turner’s rediscovery of colour and its direct appeal to the senses, regardless of subject matter. He is considered by many to be the first “abstract” artist. One of the series of films written and narrated by Sir Kenneth Clark on the painters and sculptors who from 1750 to 100 engaged in the struggle between the classic and romantic ideals.

results.title: J.M. Turner. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark and John Brabourne Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Reviews the neglected works of Turner, concentrating on alpine scenes which show how he completely understood nature. One of the series of films written and narrated by Sir Kenneth Clark on the painters and sculptors who from 1750 to 1900 engaged in the struggle between the classic and romantic ideals.

Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.

results.title: Edgar Degas
results.creator_credit: Colin Clark, Sothebys and John Brabourne Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Romantic vs classic art”.
Shows how Degas turned again and again to two themes, horse-racing and the ballet, and his use of photography as an aid to composition. Written and narrated by Kenneth Clark
